header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: One Precept Part 15

central_thesis: The singular path to spiritual reward, infinite cleaving to the Creator (Deveikut), and true consciousness is achieved solely through radical altruism—working for and giving to the public, and serving the community—while egoism, defined as any self-enjoyment, constitutes the only transgression leading to spiritual severance and corrective reincarnation.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Crux of the Matter and the Core Precept
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the foundational challenge: the current generation's insufficient collective spiritual development for widespread 'Wisdom and pure consciousness'. It then articulates the primary precept: altruistic work and giving to the public, emphasizing that its reward is infinite 'true cleaving' (Deveikut) to the Divine. Conversely, it defines the sole sin as egoism, characterized by any form of self-enjoyment.

structure_content.chapter_title: Consequences of Transgression and the Nature of Divine Service
structure_content.summary: This part details the spiritual repercussions of egoistic transgression, stating that it leads to the 'Nefesh' (Soul) being severed from human society and necessitating reincarnation for atonement. It clarifies that while the ultimate goal is 'Worshipping (or serving) the Creator,' this is practically achieved by serving one's community, as the Creator accepts such service as if directed to Him, finding pleasure in the benefit and satisfaction of those in His world.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Role of Leadership in Spiritual Understanding
structure_content.summary: The concluding section highlights the critical need to disseminate the understanding of reward and punishment in a manner accessible to the masses. It underscores that this widespread comprehension is contingent upon 'the wise' (leaders or teachers) first deeply grasping these principles, as their understanding is essential for establishing and supporting the spiritual deeds of the collective.

key_concepts.definition: The singular transgression, defined as 'any self enjoyment'. It represents an orientation towards receiving for oneself, which is spiritually detrimental and leads to separation.

key_concepts.term: Altruism (Precept to work and give to the public)
key_concepts.definition: The sole path to spiritual ascent and infinite reward. It involves consciously acting to benefit others and the Creator, adding value beyond any existing benefit, with the reward being proportional to the effort of giving.

The infinite reward for altruistic practice, signifying a deep, inseparable union with the Divine. It is described with the quote, 'no eye has seen a God besides thee' (Isaiah 64:3), indicating an experience beyond ordinary human perception.

The spiritual essence of an individual that is subjected to severance from human society and forced reincarnation as a consequence of egoistic transgression, serving as a mechanism for atonement and correction (Tikkun).

The divine contentment derived from humanity's altruistic actions. Specifically, serving one's community and providing benefit to others is considered by the Creator as direct service to Him, accepting it 'as if it came directly to Him'.

The necessary advancement of humanity as a whole, wherein a significant portion achieves 'hearts of Wisdom and pure consciousness'. This collective state is a prerequisite for higher individual and societal spiritual attainment.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined is a rigorous ethical discipline focused on cultivating radical altruism (bestowal) and eradicating egoism (reception for self). The core 'operative' mechanics involve a continuous, conscious effort to orient all actions, thoughts, and even permitted enjoyments towards giving benefit to others and the Creator. This means actively 'working and giving to the public' and 'serving one's community' with the intention of pleasing the Creator, rather than seeking personal gratification. Any 'drop of enjoyment' beyond this altruistic intention is considered a transgression, triggering a spiritual mechanism of severance and forced reincarnation for correction (Tikkun). The system posits that true spiritual progress and connection to the Divine (Deveikut) are directly proportional to one's capacity for selfless giving, effectively transforming the individual's will from 'receiving for self' to 'receiving in order to bestow'. This internal transformation is the central magical operation.
tools: The Community (as a field for altruistic practice)
Study and Understanding (for leaders and practitioners)

relevant_quotes.text: And here the is the crux of the matter (Lit. where the dog is buried), because the collectivization of our generation is not yet high enough that it would give us one-in-one-hundred people who are of hearts of Wisdom and pure consciousness.
In general, I have nothing to offer except for one precept whose reward is infinite: true cleaving, which is described as 'no eye has seen a God besides thee.' (Isaiah 64:3).
And this is the precept to work and give to the public; to add additional benefit to them on top of any benefit they already enjoy - and the reward will be according to the effort.
And right opposite to this there is only one sin, which is egoism in its most narrow sense, meaning that any self enjoyment is a transgression.

And any drop of enjoyment exceeding this degree is a transgression and the Nefesh (Soul) should be completely severed from the human society and would reincarnate, and would be put to work against his will (all this unless he atones for that sin).
And of course these things have to be in the form of 'Worshipping (or serving) the Creator' and not 'working for (or serving) the community'.

But because the Creator has provided us with ways to give Him pleasure, He has prepared a community for each individual. And it is a great rule that one should serve one's community and be useful to them.
And the Creator accepts this service and this contentment, as if it came directly to Him; in the same degree of benefit and satisfaction received by those who live in His world
Even though, for this to happen, the wise have to understand this first, because as is well known, only the understanding of the leaders establish and support the deeds of the masses.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text presents a foundational ethical-spiritual framework within the Kabbalistic tradition, particularly aligned with the teachings of Rav Yehuda Ashlag (Baal HaSulam). Its radical emphasis on altruism as the sole path to spiritual ascent and egoism as the sole transgression is a defining characteristic of Ashlagian Kabbalah. For practitioners of Western Esotericism, it provides a precise, operative model for integrating ethical conduct into spiritual work, positing that one's internal motivation—giving versus receiving—is the primary mechanism for drawing divine light and achieving union (Deveikut). This approach shifts the focus from purely ceremonial or meditative practices to the active transformation of one's will in the social sphere, thereby offering a 'magical' system for spiritual correction (Tikkun) through interpersonal engagement. It challenges practitioners to re-evaluate the purpose and effect of their actions, aligning them with a universal principle of bestowal.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes students and practitioners of Kabbalah, especially those engaged with the teachings of Rav Ashlag. More broadly, it appeals to practitioners of Western Esotericism and occultism who seek a rigorous ethical and philosophical underpinning for their magical work, particularly those interested in the 'magick of intention' or the transformative power of altruistic action. It is also relevant for spiritual leaders and teachers, as it explicitly outlines their crucial role in comprehending and conveying these complex spiritual laws to their communities.
